Will keep me for his sport, a month, or two,
To show me with my fellow citizens.
I must make his train long, and full, one quarter;
And help the spectacle of his greatness. There,
Nothing is done at once, but injuries, boy:
And they come headlong! all their good turns move not,
Or very slowly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yet sweet father, trust him.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Well, I will think ..

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Come, you must do't, sir.
I'm undone else, and your lady Tailbush
Has sent for me to dinner, and my clothes
Are all at pawn. I had sent out this morning,
Before I heard you were come to town, some twenty
Of my epistles, and no one return —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, I ha' told you o'this. This comes of wearing
Merecraft tells him of his faults. scarlet, gold lace, and cut-works! your fine gartering!
With your blown roses, cousin! and your eating
pheasant, and godwit. here in London! haunting
The globes, and mermaids! and wedging in with lords,
Still at the table! and affecting lechery,
In velvet! where could you ha' contented yourself
With cheese, salt-butter, and a pickled hearing,
I'the Low-countries; there worn cloth, and fustian!
Been satisfied with a leap o'your host's daughter,
In garrison, a wench of a stoter! or,
Your sulters wife, i'the leaguer, of two blanks!
You never, then, had run upon this flat,
To write your letters missive, and send out
Your privy seals, that thus have frighted off
All your acquaintance; that they shun you at distance,
Worse, than you do the bailies!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Pox upon you.
I come not to you for counsel,he repines, I lack money.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You do not think, what you owe me already?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I?
They owe you that mean to pay you. I'll be sworn,
I never meant it. Come, you will project, 〈◊〉
I shall undo your practice,and threatens him. for this month 〈◊〉
You know me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I you're a right sweet nature!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Well, that's all one!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You'll leave this empire, one day?
You will not ever have this tribute paid,
Your sceptre o'the sword?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Tie up your wit,
Do, and provoke me not —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you, sir, help,
To what I shall provoke another for you?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I cannot tell; try me: I think I am not
So utterly, of an ore un-to-be-melted,
But I can do myself good, on occasions.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Strike in then,they joins for your part. Mr. Fitz-dottrel
If I transgress in point of manners, afford me
Your best construction; I must beg my freedom
From your affairs, this day.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: How, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is
In succour of this gentleman's occasions,Mere-craft pretends business.
My kinsman —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: You'll not do me that affront, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am sorry you should so interpret it,
But, sir, it stands upon his being invested,
In a new, office, he has stood for, long:
Master of the dependences! Mere-craft describes the office of dependency.a place
Of my projection too, sir, and hath met
Much opposition; but the state, now see's
That great necessity of it, as after all
Their writing, and their speaking, against devils,
They have erected it. His book is drawn —
For, since, there will be differences, daily,
Betwixt gentlemen; and that the roaring manner
Is grown offensive; that those few, we call
The civil men o'the sword, abhor the vapours;
They shall refer now, hither, for their process;
And such as trespass 'gainst the rule of court,
Are to be fined —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: In troth, a pretty place!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A kind of arbitrary court 'twill be, sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I shall have matter for it, I believe,
Ere it be long: I had a distaste.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But now, sir,
My learned council, they must have a feeling,
They'll part, sir, with no books, without the hand gout
Be oiled, and I must furnish. If 't be money,
To me straight. I am mine, mint and exchequer,
To supply all. What is't? A hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: No th'harpy, now stands on a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, he must have 'em, if he will. Tomorrow, sir,
Will equally serve your occasions, —
And therefore, let me obtain, that you will yield
To timing a poor gentleman's distresses,
In terms of hazard. —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: By no means!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I must
Get him him this money, and will. —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Sir, I protest,
I'd rather stand engaged for it myself:
Than you should leave me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O good sir, do you think
So coursely of our manners, that we would,
For any need of ours, be pressed to take it:
Though you be pleased to offer it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why by heaven,
I mean it!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I can never believe less.
he offers to be gone. but we, sir, must preserve our dignity,
As you do publish yours. By your fair leave, sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman, if you do offer
To leave me now, or if you do refuse me,
I will not think you love me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, I honour you.
And with just reason, for these noble notes,
Of the nobility, you pretend too! But, sir —
I would know, why? A motive (He a stranger)
You should do this?

sp.speaker: (Eve.
sp.l: You'll mar all with your fineness)

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, that's all one, if 'twere, sir, but my fancy.
But I have a business, that perhaps I'd have
Brought to his office.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, sir! I have done, then;
If he can be made profitable, to you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, and it shall be one of my ambitions
To 〈◊〉 it the first business? May I not?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: So you do mean to make't, a perfect business.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay I'll do that assure you: show me once.
Sir▪ 〈◊〉 concerns, the first be a perfect business,
〈◊〉 his own honour!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Ay, and th'reputation
To 〈◊〉 my place.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, why, do I take this course, else?
〈◊〉 not altogether, an ass, good gentlemen,
Wherefore should I consult you? do you think?
To make a song on't? How's your manner? tell us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do, satisfy him: give him the whole course.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: First, by request, or otherwise you offer
Your business to the court: wherein you crave:
The judgement of the master and the assistants.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, that's done, now, what do you upon it ▪

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: We straight sir, have recourse to the springhead;
visit the ground; and so disclose the nature:
If it will carry, or no. If we do find,
By your proportions it is like to prove
A sullen, and black business that it be
Incorrigible; and out of, treaty; then,
We file it, a dependence!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: So 'tis filled.
What follows? I do love the order of these things.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: We then advise the party, if he be
A man of means and havings ▪ that forthwith,
He settle his estate: if not, at least
That he pretend it. For, by that, the world
Takes notice, that enough is a dependence.
And this we call, sir, publication.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Very sufficient! After publication, now?

sp.speaker: Eve
sp.l: Then we grant out our process, which is divers ▪
Either by cartel, sir, or oretenus,
Wherein the challenger, and challengee
Or (With your Spaniard) your provocador,
And provocado, have their several courses —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I have enough on't! for an hundred pieces?
Yes, for two hundred, underwrite me do.
Your man will take my bond?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That he will, sure,
But, these same citizens, they are such sharks!
There's an old debt of forty,he whispers Fitz-dottrel aside. I ga' my word
For one is run away, into the Bermudas,
And he will hook in that, or he wi'not do.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why let him. That and the ring, and a hundred pieces,
Will all but make two hundred?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No,and then Guilt-head. no more, sir.
What ready arithmetic you have? do you hear?
A pretty morning's work for you, this? Do it,
You shall ha' twenty pound on't.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Twenty pieces?

sp.speaker: (Plu.
sp.l: Good father, do't)

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You will hook still? well ▪
Show us your ring. You could not ha'done this, now
With gentleness, at first, we might ha' thanked you ▪
But groan, and ha' your courtesies come from you
Like a hard stool, and stink? A man may draw
Your teeth out easier, than your money? Come,
Were little Guilt-head here, no better a nature,
I should ne'er love him,he pulls Plutarchus by the lips. that could pull his lips off, now ▪
Was not thy mother a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And went to the court at Christmas, and st. Georges-tide?
And lent the lords-men, chains?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Of gold, and pearl, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I knew, thou must take, after somebody !
Thou couldst not be else. This was no shop-look
I'll ha'thee captain Guilt-head, and march up,
And take in Pimlico, and kill the bush,
At every tavern! Thou shalt have a wife,
If smocks will mount,he turns to old Guilt-head. boy. How now? you ha'there now
Some bristo-stone, or Cornish counterfeit
You'd put upon us.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: No, sir, I assure you:
look on his luster! he will speak himself!
I'll gi' you leave to put him i'the mill,
He's no great, large stone, but a true paragon,
H'has all his corners, view him well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He's yellow.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Upo' my faith, sir, o'the right blackwater,
And very deep! He's set without a foil, too.
Here's one o'the yellow water, I'll sell cheap.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And what do you value this at? thirty pound?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: No, sir, he cost me forty, ere he was set.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Turnings, you mean? I know your equinoxes ▪
You're grown the better fathers of'hem o'late,
Well, where't must go, 'twill be judged, and therefore,
Look you't be right. You shall have fifty pound for't.
now to Fitz-dottrel.not a denier more! And because you would
Have things dispatched, sir, I'll go presently,
Inquire out this lady, if you think good sir.
Having an hundred pieces ready, you may
Part with those, now, to serve my kinsman's turns,
That he may wait upon you, anon, the freer;
And take 'em when you ha' sealed, again, of Guilt-head.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I care not if I do!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And dispatch all,
Together,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: They're just: a hundred pieces!
I' ha' told 'em over, twice a day, these two months.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: he turns 'em out together. And Ever-ill and he fall to share. well, go and seal then, sir, make your return
As speedy as you can.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come give me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Soft sir.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Marry, and fair too, then. I'll no delaying, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But you will hear?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Yes, when I have my dividend.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There's forty pieces for you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: What is this for?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your half. You know that Guilt-head must ha' twenty.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And what's your ring there? shall I ha' none o'that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, that's to be given to a lady!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Is't so?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: By that good light, it is.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, gi'me
Ten pieces more then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: For guilt, head? Sir,
Do you think, I'll 'low him any such share.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Must I? Do you your musts, sir, I'll do mine,
You wi'not part with the whole, sir? Will you? Go too.
Give me ten pieces!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: By what law do you this?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: E'en lion-law, sir, I must roar else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: You've heard, how th' ass made his divisions wisely?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And I am he, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Much good do you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I shall be rid o'this tyranny, one day?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Not,
While you do eat, and lie about the town here;
And cozen i'your bullions and I stand
Your name of credit, and compound your business;
Adjourn beatings every term; and make
New parties for your projects. I have now
A pretty task of it, to hold you in
Wi' your lady Tail-bush: but the toy will be,
How we shall both come off?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Leave your doubting,
And do your portion, what's assigned you: I
never failed yet.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: With reference to your aides?
You'll still be unthankful. Where shall I meet you anon?
You ha' some feat to be done alone, now, I see;
You wish me gone, well, I will find you out,
And bring you after to the audit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Slight!
There's engines share too ▪ I had forgotten! This reign
Is too-too unsupportable! I must
Quit myself of this vassalage! Engine! welcome.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Iv.
div.l: How goes the cry?

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: Excellent well!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wil't do?
Where's Robinson?

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: Here is the gentleman, sir.
Will undertake t'himself. I have acquainted him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why did you so?

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: Why, Robinson would ha' told him,
You know. And he's a pleasant wit! will hurt
Nothing you purpose. Then, he's of opinion,
That Robinson might have audacity,
She being such a gallant. Now, he has been,
In Spain, and knows the fashions there, and can
Discourse; and being but mirth (He says) leave much,
To his care:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But he is too tall!

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: For that,
He has the bravest device! he excepts at his stature. (You'll love him for't)
To say, he wears chopins: and they do so
In Spain. And robinson's as tall, as he.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: Every jot.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, I had rather
To trust a gentleman with it, o'the two.

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: Pray you go to him, then, sir, and salute him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, my friend engine has acquainted you
With a strange business, here.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A merry one, sir.
The Duke of drowned land, and his Duchess?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, sir.
Now, that the conjurers ha' laid him by,
I ha' made bold to borrow him a while;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: With purpose, yet, to put him out I hope
To his best use?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For that small part,
That I am trusted with, put off your care:
I would not lose to do it, for the mirth,
Will follow of it; and well I have a fancy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, that will make it well.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You will report it so.
Where must I have my dressing?

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: At my house, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You shall have caution, sir, for what he yields,
To six pence.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You shall pardon me. I will share, sir,
I' your sports, only: nothing i'your purchase.
But you must furnish me with compliments,
To th'manner of Spain; my coach, my guarda duennas;

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Engine's your pro'vedor. But, sir, I must
(Now I've entered trust wi'you, thus far)
secure still i'your quality, acquaint you
With somewhat, beyond this. The place designed
To be the scene, for this our merry matter,
Because it must have countenance of women,
To draw discourse, and offer it, is hereby,
At the lady Tail-bush's.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I know her, sir ▪
And her gentleman usher.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Mr. Ambler?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, it shall be no shame to me, to confess
To you that we poor gentlemen, that want acres,
Must for our needs, turn fools up, and plough ladies
Sometimes, to try what glebe they are: and this
Is no unfruitful piece. She and I now,
Are on a project for the fact, and venting
Of a new kind of fucus (Paint for ladies)
To serve the kingdom: wherein she herself
Hath travelled, specially by way of service
Unto her sex, and hopes to get the monopoly,
As the reward of her invention.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What is her end, in this ▪
Merely ambition,
Sir, to grow great, and court it with the secret:
Though she pretend some other. For she's dealing,
Already, upon caution for the shares,
And Mr. Ambler, is he named examiner
For the ingredients; and the register
Of what is vented; and shall keep the office.
Now, if she break with you, of this (As I
Must make the leading thread to your acquaintance,
That how experience gotten i'your being
Abroad, will help our business) think of some
Pretty additions, but to keep her floating:
It may be, she will offer you a part,
Any strange names of —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, I have my instructions.
Is it not high time to be making ready?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, sir,

sp.speaker: Ingine
sp.l: The fool's in sight, Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Away then.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. V.
div.l: Returned so soon?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, here's the ring: I ha' sealed.
But there's not so much gold in all the row, he says —
Till't come fro' the mint. 'tis ta'en up for the gamesters.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There's a shop-shift! plague on 'em.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: He does swear it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He'll swear, and forswear too, it is his trade,
You should not have left him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'Slid, I can go back,
And beat him, yet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, now let him alone.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I was so earnest, after the main business,
To have this ring, gone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True, and 'tis time.
I have learned, sir, sin'you went, her ladyship eats
with the lady Tailbush, here, hard by.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I'the lane here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, if you'd a servant, now of presence,
Well clothed, and of an aery voluble tongue,
Neither too big, or little for his mouth,
That could deliver your wife's compliment;
To send along withal.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I have one sir,
A very handsome, gentleman-like-fellow,
That I do mean to make my Duchess usher —
I entertained him, but this morning, too:
I'll call him to you. The worst of him, is his name!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She'll take no note of that, but of his message.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Devil! he shows him his Pug.how like you him, sir. Pace, go a little.
Let's see you move.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He'll serve, sir, give it him:
And let him go along with me, I'll help
To present him, and it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Look, you do sirrah,
Discharge this well, as you expect your place.
D'ye hear,gives him instructions. go on, come off with all your honours.
I would fain see him, do it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Trust him, with it;

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Remember kissing of your hand, and answering
With the french-time, in flexure of your body.
I could not so instruct him — and for his words —

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: I'll put them in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, but I have 'em
O'the very academies!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, you'll have use for 'em,
Anon,he longs to see the play. yourself, I warrant you: after dinner,
When you are called.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'Slight, that'll be just playtime.
It cannot be, I must not lose the play!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir,because it is the devil. but you must, if she appoint to sit.
And, she's precedent.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'Slid, it is the devil!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And 'twere his dam too, you must now apply
Yourself, sir, to this, wholly; or lose all.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: If I could but see a piece —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir. Never think on't.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come but to one act, and I did not care —
But to be seen to rise, and go away,
To vex the players, and to punish their poet —
Keep him in awe!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But say, that he be on't,
Wi'not be awed ● but laugh at you. How then?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Then he shall pay for his dinner himself.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Perhaps,
He would do that twice, rather than thank you.
Come, get the devil out of your head, my lord,
(I'll call you so in private still) and take
Your lordship i'your mind. he puts him in mind of his quarrel. you were, sweet lord,
In talk to bring a business to the office.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why should not you, sir, carry it o'your self,
Before the office be up? and show the world,
You had no need of any man's direction;
In point, sir, of sufficiency. I speak
Against a kinsman, but as one that tenders
Your grace's good.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I thank you; to proceed —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To publications: ha' your deed drawn presently.
And leave a blank to put in your feoffs
one, two, or more, as you see cause —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I thank you
Heartily, I do thank you. Not a word more,
I pray you, as you love me. Let me alone.
he is angry with himself. that I could not think o'this, as well as he?
O, I could beat my infinite blockhead —!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Come, we must this way.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: How far is't.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hard by here
Over the way. Now, to achieve this ring,
he thinks how to cozen the bearer of the ring. from this same fellow, that is to assure it;
Before he give it. Though my Spanish lady,
Be a young gentleman of means, and scorn
To share as he doth say, I do not know
How such a toy may tempt his ladyship:
And therefore, I think best, it be assured.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir, be the ladies brave, we go unto?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, yes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And shall I see 'em, and speak to 'em?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: questions his man. what else? ha'you your false beard about you? Trains.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And is this one of your double cloaks?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The best of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Be ready then. Sweet Pitfall!

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Vi.
div.l: Come, I must buss —

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I'll set thee up again;
offers to kiss. never fear that: canst thou get ne'er a bird?
No thrushes hungry? Stay till cold weather come,
I'll help thee to an ouzel, or a fieldfare.
she runs in, in haste: he follows. who's within with madam?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: I'll tell you straight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Please you stay here a while sir, I'll go in.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I do so long to have a little venery,
Pug leaps at Pitfall's coming in. while I am in this body! I would taste
Of every sin, a little, if it might be
After the manner of man! Sweet heart!

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: What would you, sir?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Nothing but fall in, to you, be your blackbird,
My pretty pit (As the gentleman said) your throstle:
Lie tame, and taken with you; here's gold!
To buy you so much new stuffs from the shop,
Traine's in his false cloak brings a false message, and gets the ring. as I may take the old up —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You must send, sir,
The gentleman the ring.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: There 'tis. Nay look,
Will you be foolish, pit.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: This is strange rudeness.

sp.speaker: Pug
sp.l: Dear pit.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: I'll call, I swear.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Where are you, sir?
Is your ring ready? Go with me.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I sent it you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: mere craft follows presently, and asks for it. me? When? by whom?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A fellow here, e'en now,
Came for it i'your name.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I sent none, sure.
My meaning ever was, you should deliver it,
Yourself: so was your master's charge, you know.
ent. Train's as himself again. what fellow was it, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Here,
But now, he had it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Saw you any? Trains?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The gentleman saw him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Inquire.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I was so earnest upon her, I marked not! the devil confesseth himself cozened.
My devilish chief has put me here in flesh,
To shame me! This dull body I am in,
I perceive nothing with! I offer at nothing,
That will succeed!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sir, she saw none, she says.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Satan himself, has ta'en a shape t'abuse me.
It could not be else! Mere-craft accuseth him of negligence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This is above strange?
That you should be so reckless. What'll you do sir?
How will you answer this, when you are questioned?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Run from my flesh, if I could: put off mankind!
This's such a scorn! and will be a new exercise,
For my archduke! Woe to the several cudgels,
Must suffer,he asketh aid. on this back! Can you no suckers? Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Alas! use of it is so present.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I ask,
Sir, credit for another, but till tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There is not so much time, sir. But however ,
The lady is a noble lady, and will
(To save a gentleman from check) be entreatedMerecraft promiseth faintly, yet comforts him.
To say, she has received it.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Do you think so?
Will she be won?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No doubt, to such an office,
It will be a lady's bravery, and her pride.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And not be known on't after, unto him?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That were a treachery! Upon my word.
Be confident. Return unto your master,
My lady president sits this afternoon,
Has ta'en the ring, commends her services
Unto your lady-duchess. You may say
She's a civil lady, and does give her
All her respects, already: bade you tell her
She lives, but to receive her wished commandments,
And have the honour here to kiss her hands:
For which she'll stay this hour yet. Hasten you
Your prince, away.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And sir, you will take care
Th'excuse be perfect? the devil is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You confess your fears.
Too much.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The shame is more, I'll quit you of either.

div.head: Act. vi. scene. i.
div.l: A pox upon 'Referring to commissioners,
I'had rather hear that it were passed the seals:
Your courtiers move so snail-like i'your business.
Would I had not begun wi'you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: We must move,
Madam, in order, by degrees ● not jump.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: Why, there was sr. John M●mis-man could jump
a business quickly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True he had great friends,
But because some, sweet madam, can leap ditches,
We must not all shun to go over bridges,
The harder parts, I make account are done:
he flatters her. now 'tis referred. You are infinitely bound
Unto the ladies, they ha' so cried it up!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Do they like it then?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They ha' sent the Spanish lady
To gratulate with you —

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I must send 'em thanks
And some remembrances.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That you must, and visit 'em.
Where's Ambler?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Lost today, we cannot hear of him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Not madam?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: No in good faith. They say he lay not
At home tonight , and here has fallen a business
Between your cousin and master manly, has
Unquieted us all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So I hear, madam.
Pray you how was it?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Troth, it but appears
Ill o'your kinsman's part. You may have heard,
That manly is a suitor to me, I doubt not:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I guessed it, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And it seems he trusted
Your cousin to let fall some fair reports
Of him unto me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Which he did!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So far
From it, as he came in and took him railing
Against him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How! And what said manly to him?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Enough, I do assure you: and with that scorn
Of him, and the injury, as I do wonder
How Ever-ill bore it! But that guilt undoes
Many men's valours.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Here comes manly. Man. madam,
Manly offers to be gone. I'll take my leave —

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: You sha'not go, i'faith.
I'll ha' you stay and see this Spanish miracle,
Of our English lady.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me pray your ladyship,
Lay your commands on me some other time.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Now, I protest: and I will have all pieced,
And friends again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It will be but ill soldered!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: You are too much affected with it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I cannot
Madam, but think on't for th'injustice.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sir,
Mere-craft denies him. his kinsman here is sorry. Not I madam,
I am no kin to him, we but call cousins,
And if we were, I have no relation
Unto his crimes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are not urged with 'em.
I can accuse sir, none but mine own judgement,
For though it were his crime so to betray me:
I am sure 'twas more mine own, at all to trust him.
But he therein did use but his old manners,
And favor strongly what he was before.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Come, he will change!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Faith, I must never think it.
Nor were it reason in me to expect
That for my sake, he should put off a nature
He sucked in with his milk. It may be madam,
Deceiving trust is all he has to trust to:
If so, I shall be loath that any hope
Of mine should bate him of his means.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: You're sharp sir.
This act may make him honest!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If he were
To be made honest, by an act of parliament,
I should not alter,she spies the lady Either-side. i'my faith of him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Either-side!
Welcome, dear Either-side! how hast thou done, good wench?
Thou hast been a stranger! I ha' not seen thee, this week.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. Ii.
div.l: Ever your servant, madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Where hast'hou been?
I did so long to see thee.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Visiting, and so tired!
I protest, madam, 'tis a monstrous trouble!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And so it is. I swear I must tomorrow,
Begin my visits (Would they were over) at court.
It tortures me, to think on 'em.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I do hear
You ha' cause, madam, your suit goes on.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Who told thee?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: One, that can tell: Mr. Either-side.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, thy husband!
Yes faith, their's life in't, now: it is referred.
If we once see it under the seals, wench, then,
Have with 'em for the great caroche, six horses,
And the two coachmen, with my Ambler, bare,
And my three women: we will live, i'faith,
The examples o'the town, and govern it.
I'll lead the fashion still.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: You do that, now,
Sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, but then, I'll every day
Bring up some new device. Thou and I, Either-side,
Will first be in it, I will give it thee;
And they shall follow us. Thou shalt, I swear,
Wear every month a new gown, out of it.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Thank you good madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pray thee call me Tail-bush
As I thee, Either-side; I not love this, madam.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Then I protest to you tail bush, I am glad
Your business so succeeds.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Thank thee, good Either-side.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: But Mr. Either-side tells me, that he likes
Your other business better.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Which?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O, the toothpicks.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I never heard on't.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Ask Mr. Merecraft.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Madam? He's one, in a word, I'll trust his malice,
With any man's credit,Mere-craft hath whispered with the while. I would have abused!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, if you think you do please me, in this,
You are deceived!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, but because my lady,
Named him my kinsman, I would satisfy you,
What I think of him: and pray you, upon it
To judge me!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So I do: that ill men's friendship,
Is as unfaithful, as themselves.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Do you hear?
Ha'you a business about toothpicks?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, madam.
Did I ne'er tell't you? I meant to have offered it
Your ladyship, on the perfecting the patent.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How is't!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For serving the whole state with tooth picks;
(Somewhat in intricate business to discourse) but —
the project for toothpicks. I show, how much the subject is abused,
First in that one commodity? then what diseases,
And putrefactions in the gums are bred,
By those are made 'Of' adulterate, and false wood?
My plot, for reformation of these, follows.
To have all toothpicks, brought unto an office,
There sealed; and such as counterfeit 'em, mulcted.
And last, for venting 'em to have a book
Printed, to teach their use, which every child
Shall have throughout the kingdom, that can read,
And learn to pick his teeth by. Which beginning
Early to practice, with some other rules,
Of never sleeping with the mouth open, chawing
Some grains of mastic, will preserve the breath
trains his man whispers him. pure, and so free from taint — ha'what is't? sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good faith, it sounds a very pretty business!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: So Mr. Either-side says, madam.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The lady is come.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Is she? Good, wait upon her in. My Ambler
Was never so ill absent. Either-side,
How do I look today? Am I not dressed,
she looks in her glass. Spruntly?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, verily, madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pox o' madam,
Will you not leave that?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Yes good Tailbush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So?
Sounds not that better? What vile fucus is this,
Thou hast got on?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: 'Tis pearl.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pearl? oyster-shells:
As I breathe, Either-side, I know't. Here comes
(They say) a wonder, sirrah, has been in Spain!
Will teach us all! she's sent to me, from court.
To gratulate with me! Prithee , let's observe her,
What faults she has, that we may laugh at 'em,
When she is gone.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: That we will heartily, tail bush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Wittipol enters. o, me! the very infanta of the giants!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Here is a noble lady, madam, come,
Wittipol is dressed like a Spanish lady. from your great friends, at court, to see your ladyship:
And have the honour of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sir.
She does us honour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray you, say to her ladyship,
It is the manner of Spain, to embrace only,
excuses himself for not kissing. never to kiss. She will excuse the custom!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Your use of it is law. Please you, sweet madam,
To take a seat.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, madam, I've had
The favour, through a world of fair report
To know your virtues, madam,; and in that
Name have deserved the happiness of presenting
My service to your ladyship!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Your love, madam,
I must not own it else.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Both are due madam,
To your great undertakings.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Great? In troth, madam,
They are my friends, that think 'em any thing:
If I can do my sex (By 'em) any service,
I've my ends, madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And they are noble ones,
That make a multitude beholden, madam:
The commonwealth of ladies, must acknowledge from you.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Except some envious, madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You're right in that, madam,
Of which race, I encountered some but lately.
Who ('t seems) have studied reasons to discredit
Your business.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How sweet madames?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, the parties
Wi'not be worth your pause — most ruinous things, madam,
That have put off all hope of being recovered ▪
To a degree of handsomeness.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But their reasons, madam?
I would fain hear.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Some madam, I remember.
They say, that painting quite destroys the face —

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O, that's an old one, madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: There are new ones, too.
Corrupts the breath; hath left so little sweetness
In kissing, as 'tis now used, but for fashion:
And shortly will be taken for a punishment.
Decays the foreteeth, that should guard the tongue;
And suffers that run riot everlasting!
And (Which is worse) some ladies when they meet
Cannot be merry,Manly begins to know him. and laugh, but they do spit
In one another's faces!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I should know
This voice, and face too:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Then they say, 'tis dangerous
To all the fallen, yet well disposed mad-dames,
That are industrious, and desire to earn
Their living with their sweat! For any distemper
Of heat, and motion, may displace the colours;
And if the paint once run about their faces,
Twenty to one, they will appear so ill-favoured,
Their servants run away, too, and leave the pleasure
Imperfect, and the reckoning als' unpaid.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Pox, these are poets' reasons.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Some old lady
That keeps a poet, has devised these scandals.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Faith we must have the poets banished, madam,
As master Either-side says.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Master Fitz-dottrell?
And his wife: where? madam, the Duke of Drowned-land,
That will be shortly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Is this my lord?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The same.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Fitz-dottrell. Mistress Fitz-dottrell. Pug. to them.
div.l: Your servant,Wittipol whispers with Manly. madam!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How now? Friend? offended,
That I have found your haunt here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No but wondering
At your strange fashioned venture, hither.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It is
To show you what they are, you so pursue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I think 'twill prove a medicine against marriage;
To know their manners.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Stay, and profit then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The lady, madam, whose prince has brought her here,
he presents mistress Fitz-dottrell. to be instructed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Please you sit with us lady.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That's lady-president.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A goodly woman!
I cannot see the ring, though.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, she has it.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But madam, these are very feeble reasons!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So I urged madam, that the new complexion,
Now to come forth, in name o'your ladyship's fucus,
Had no ingredient —

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But I durst eat, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So do they in Spain.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sweet madam be so liberal,
To give us some o'your Spanish fucuses!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: They are infinite madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So I hear they have
Water of gourds, of radish, the white beans,
Flowers of glass, of thistles, rose-marine.
Raw honey, mustardseed, and bread dough-baked,
The crumbs o'bread, goat's milk, and whites of eggs,
Campher and lily-roots, the fat of swans,
Marrow of veal, white pigeons, and pine-kernels,
The seed of nettles, purslane, and hare's gall.
Lemons, thine skinned —

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: How, her ladyship has studied
All excellent things!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But ordinary madam,
No, the true rarities are th'alvagada,
And argentata of Queen Isabella!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Ay, what are their ingredients, gentle madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Your alum Scagliola, or Polidipedra;
And zuccarino; turpentine of Abezzo,
Washed in nine waters: soda di gotta;
Grosia di serpe; porcelleto marino;
Oils of Lentisco; zucchi Mugia; make
The admirable varnish for the face,
Gives the right luster; but two drops rubbed on
With a piece of scarlet, makes a lady of sixty
Look at sixteen. But above all, the water
Of the white hen, of the lady Estifanias!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O ay, that same good madam, I have heard of:
How is it done?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Madam, you take your hen,
Plume it, and skin it, cleanse it o'the innards:
Then chop it, bones and all: add to four ounces
Of carrnuacinss, pipitas, soap of Cyprus,
Make the decoction, strain it. Then distil it,
And keep it in your galley-pot well gliddered:
Three drops preserves from wrinkles, warts, spots, moles,
Blemish, or sun-burnings, and keeps the skin
In decimo sexto, ever bright, and smooth,
As any lookingglass; and indeed is called
The virgin's milk for the face, Oglioreale;
A ceruse, neither cold or heat will hurt;
And mixed with oil of myrrh, and the red gillyflower
called cataputia; and flowers of Rovistico;
Makes the best muta ▪ or die of the whole world.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Dear madam, will you let us be familiar?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Your ladyship's servant.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How do you like her.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Admirable!
But,he is jealous about his ring, and Merecraft delivers it. yet, I cannot see the ring.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I must
Deliver it, or mar all. This fool's so jealous.
Madam — sir, wear this ring, and pray you take knowledge,
'Twas sent you by his wife. And give her thanks,
Do not you dwindle, sir, bear up.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But for the manner of Spain! Sweet, madam, let us
Be bold, now we are in: are all ladies,
There, i'the fashion?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: None but grandees, madam.
O'the clasped train, which may be worn at length, too,
Or thus, upon my arm.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And do they wear
Chopinoes all?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If they be dressed in punto, madam.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Guilt as those are? madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Of goldsmith's work, madam;
And set with diamonds: and their Spanish pumps
Of perfumed leather.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I should think it hard
To go in 'em, madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: At the first, it is, madam.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: Do you never fall in 'em?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I swear, I should
Six times an hour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But you have men at hand, still,
To help you, if you fall?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Only one, madam,
The guardo duennas, such a little old man,
As this.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Alas! he can do nothing! this!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I'll tell you, madam, I saw i'the court of Spain once,
A lady fall i'the King's sight, along.
And there she lay, flat spread, as an umbrella,
Her hoop here cracked; no man durst reach a hand
To help her, till the guarda duenn as came,
Who is the person one l'allowed to touch
A lady there: and he but by this finger.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Ha' they no servants, madam, there ▪ nor friends?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: An escudero, or so madam, that waits
Upon 'em in another coach, at distance,
And when they walk, or dance, holds by a handkercher,
Never presumes to touch 'em.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: This's scurvy!
And a forced gravity! I do not like it.
I like our own much better.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: 'Tis more French,
And courtly ours.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: And tastes more liberty.
We may have our dozen of visiters, at once,
Make love t'us.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And before our husbands?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Husband?
As I am honest, Tail-bush I do think
If nobody should love me, but my poor husband,
I should e'en hang myself.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Fortune forbid, wench:
So fair a neck should have so foul a necklace,

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: 'Tis true, as I am handsome!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I received, lady,
A token from you, which I would not be
Rude to refuse, being your first remembrance.

sp.speaker: (Fit.
sp.l: Oh, I am satisfied now!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you see it, sir.)

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But since you come, to know me, nearer, lady,
I'll beg the honour, you will wear it for me,
It must be so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Fit.
sp.l: Surely I have heard this tongue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Would you ha' me mercenary?
Wittipol gives it mistress Fitz-dottrell. Merecraft murmurs. He is satisfied, now he sees it. we'll recompense it anon, in somewhat else.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I do not love to be gulled, though in a toy.
Wife, do you hear? you're come in the school, wife,
Where you may learn, I do perceive it, any thing!
How to be fine, or fair, or great, or proud,
Or what you will, indeed, wife; here 'tis taught.
And I am glad on't, that you may not say,
Another day, when honours come upon you,
You wanted means. I ha'done my parts: been,
he upbraids her with his bill of costs. today at fifty pound charge, first, for a ring,
To get you entered. Then let my new play ▪
To wait upon you, here, to see't confirmed.
That I may say, both to mine own eyes, and ears,
Senses, you are my witness, sh'hath enjoyed
All helps that could be had for love or money —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fit.
sp.l: To make a fool of her.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wife, that's your malice,
The wickedness o'your nature to interpret
Your husband's kindness thus. But I'll not leave;
Still to do good for your depraved affections:
Intend it. Bend this stubborn will; be great.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good madam, whom do they use in messages?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: They commonly use their slaves madam.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: And does your ladyship.
Think that so good, madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No indeed madam; ay,
Therein prefer the fashion of England far,
Of your young delicate page, or discreet usher.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And I go with your ladyship in opinion,
Directly for your gentleman-usher,
There's not a finer officer goes on ground.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If he be made and broken to his place once.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay so I presuppose him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And they are fitter
Managers too sir, but I would have 'em called
Our escuderoes.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Say I should send
To your ladyship, who (I presume) has gathered
All the dear secrets to know how to make
Pastillos of the Duchess of Braganza,
Coquettas, almoiavana's, Mantecada's,
Alcoreas, mustaccioli; or say it were
The peladore of Isabella, or balls
Against the itch, or aqua nanfa, or oil
Of jasmine for gloves, of the marquess Muja;
Or for the head and hair: why, these are offices.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fit for a gentleman, not a slave. They only
Might ask for your pivety, spanish-coal,
To burn and sweeten a room: but the arcana
he enters himself with the ladies. of ladies' cabinets —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Should be elsewhere trusted.
You're much about the truth. Sweet honoured ladies,
Let me fall in wi'you. I ha' my female wit,
as well as my male. And I do know what suits
A lady of spirit, or a woman of fashion!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And you would have your wife such.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, madam, aery,
Light; not to plain dishonesty, I mean:
But, somewhat o'this side.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I take you, sir.
H'has reason ladies. I'll not give this rush
For any lady, that cannot be honest
Within a thread.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes, madam, and yet venture
As far for th'other, in her fame —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: As can be;
Coach it to Pimlico; dance the saraband,
Hear, and talk bawdy; laugh as loud, as a alarm;
Squeak, spring, do any thing.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: In young company, madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Or afore gallants. If they be brave, or lords,
A woman is engaged.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I say so, ladies,
It is civility to deny us nothing.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: You talk of a university! why, hell is
A grammar-school to this!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: But then,the devil admires him.
She must not lose a look on stuffs, or cloth, madam.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Nor no course fellow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: She must be guided, madam
By the clothes he wears, and company he is in;
Whom to salute, how far —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I ha' told her this.
And how that bawdry too, upo'the point,
Is (In itself) as civil a discourse —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: As any other affair of flesh, whatever .

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But she will ne'er be capable, she is not
So much as coming, madam; I know not how
She loses all her opportunities
With hoping to be forced. he shows his Pug.I've entertained
A gentleman, a younger brother, here,
Whom I would fain breed up, her escudero,
Against some expectations that I have,
And she'll not countenance him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Devil, o'darby-shire.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Bless us from him!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Devil?
Call him devil, sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Fit.
sp.l: What you please, ladies.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: De-vile's a prettier name!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: And sounds, methinks ,
As it came in with the conqueror —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Over smocks!
What things they are? That nature should be at leisure
Ever to make 'em!Manly goes out with indignation. my wooing is at an end.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What can he do?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Let's hear him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Can he manage?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Please you to try him, ladies. Stand forth, devil.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Was all this but the preface to my torment?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come, let their ladyship see your honours.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O,
He makes a wicked leg.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: As ever I saw!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Fit for a devil.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good madam, call him devil.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Devil, what property is there most required
I'your conceit, now, in the escudero?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why do you not speak?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A settled discreet pause,they begin their catechism. madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I think, a barren head, sir, mountainlike,
To be exposed to the cruelty of weathers —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ay, for his valley is beneath the waste, madam,
and to be fruitful there, it is sufficient.
Dullness upon you! Could not you hit this?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Good sir —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He then had had no barren head.
he strikes him. you daw him too much, in troth, sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I must walk
With the French stick, like an old verger, for you.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: the devil prays. o, chief, call me to hell again, and free me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Do you murmur now?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What do you take
Mr. devil, the height of your employment,
In the true perfect escudero?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: When?
What do you answer?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: To be able, madam,
First to inquire, then report the working,
Of any lady's physic, in sweet phrase,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, that's an act of elegance, and importance.
But what above?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, that I had a goad for him.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: To find out a good corn-cutter.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Out on him!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Most barbarous!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why did you do this, now?
Of purpose to discredit me? you damned devil.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sure, if I be not yet, I shall be. All
My days in hell, were holidays to this!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: 'Tis labour lost, madam?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: He's a dull fellow
Of no capacity!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Of no discourse!
O, if my Ambler had been here!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Ay, madam;
You talk of a man, where is there such another?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Mr. Devile, put case, one of my ladies, here,
Had a fine brach: and would employ you forth
To treat about a convenient match for her.
What would you observe?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The colour, and the size, madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: The moon, you calf, the moon!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Ay, and the sign.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes, and receipts for proneness.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Then when the puppies came, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Get their nativities cast!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This's well. What more?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Consult the almanac-man which would be least?
Which cleanliest?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And which silentest? This's well, madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And while she were with puppy?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Walk her out,
And air her every morning!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Very good!
And be industrious to kill her fleas?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Yes!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He will make a pretty proficient.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Who,
Coming from hell, could look for such catechising?
The devil is an ass. I do acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fitz-dottrel admires Wittipol.the top of woman! All her sex in abstract!
I love her, to each syllable, falls from her.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good madam give me leave to go aside with him!
And try him a little!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Do, and I'll withdraw, madam,
the devil prays again. with this fair lady: read to her the while.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Come, sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Dear chief, relieve me, or I perish.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Lady, we'll follow. You are not jealous sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, madame! you shall see. Stay wife, behold,
he gives his wife to him, taking him to be a lady. I give her up here, absolutely, to you,
She is your own. Do with her what you will!
Melt, cast, and form her as you shall think good!
Set any stamp on! I'll receive her from you
As a new thing, by your own standard!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well, sir!

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Iii.
div.l: But what ha'you done i'your dependence, since?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, it goes on, I met your cousin, the master —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You did not acquaint him, sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Faith, but I did, sir.
And upon better thought, not without reason!
He being chief officer, might ha' ta'ne it ill, else,
As a contempt against his place, and that
In time sir, ha'drawn on another dependence.
No, I did find him in good terms, and ready
To do me any service.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So he said to you?
But sir, you do not know him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, I presumed
Because this business of my wives, required me,
I could not ha'done better: and he told
Me, that he would go presently to your council,
A knight, here, i'the lane —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, justice Either-side.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And get the feoffment drawn, with a letter of attorney.
For livery and seizin!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That I know's the course.
But, sir, you mean not to make him feoffee?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, that I'll pause on!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How now little Pitfall?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Your cousin Mr. Everill, would come in —
But he would know if master manly were here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No,Merecraft whispers against him. tell him, if he were, I ha' made his peace!
He's one, sir, has no state, and a man knows not,
How such a trust may tempt him.

sp.speaker: Fit:
sp.l: I conceive you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir, this same deed is done here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pretty Plutarchus?
Art thou come with it? and has sir Paul viewed it?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His hand is to the draught.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you step in, sir,
And read it?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I pray you a word wi'you,Everil whispers against Merecraft.
Sir Paul Either-side willed me give you caution
Whom you did make feoffee: for 'tis the trust
O'your whole state: and though my cousin here
Be a worthy gentleman, yet his valour has
At the tall board been questioned; and we hold
Any man so impeached of doubtful honesty!
I will not justify this; but give it you
To make your profit of it: if you utter it,
I can forswear it!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I believe you, and thank you, sir.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Vi.
div.l: Be not afraid, sweet lady: you're trusted
To love, not violence here; I am no ravisher,
But one, whom you, by your fair trust again,
May of a servant make a most true friend.

sp.speaker: Mis. Fit.
sp.l: And such a one I need, but not this way:
Sir, I confess me to you, the mere manner
Of your attempting me, this morning took me,
And I did hold m'invention, and my manners,
Were both engaged, to give it a requital;
But not unto your ends: my hope was then,
(Though interrupted, ere it could be uttered)
That whom I found the master of such language,
That brain and spirit, for such an enterprise,
Could not but if those succours were demanded
To a right use, employ them virtuously!
And make that profit of his noble parts,
Which they would yield. Sir, you have now the ground,
To exercise them in: I am a woman,
That cannot speak more wretchedness of myself,
Than you can read; marched to a mass of folly;
That every day makes haste to his own ruin;
The wealthy portion, that I brought him, spent;
And (Through my friends neglect) no jointure made me.
My fortune's standing in this precipice,
'Tis counsel that I want, and honest aides:
And in this name, I need you, for a friend!
Never in any other; for his ill,
Must not make me, sir, worse.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O friend! forsake not
Manly, concealed this while, shows himself. the brave occasion, virtue offers you,
To keep you innocent: I have feared for both;
And watched you to prevent the ill I feared.
But since the weaker side hath so assured me,
Let not the stronger fall by his own vice,
Or be the less a friend, cause virtue needs him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Virtue shall never ask my succours twice;
Most friend, most man; your counsels are commands:
Lady, I can love goodness in you, more
Than I did beauty; and do here entitle
Your virtue to the power, upon a life
Meere-craft takes Wittipol aside, and moves a project for himself. you shall engage in any faithful service,
Even to forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Madam: do you hear, sir,
We have another leg-strained, for this dotterel.
He's a quarrel to carry, and has caused
A deed of feoffment, of his whole estate
to be drawn yonder; hast within: and you,
Only, he means to make feoffee. He's fallen
So desperately enamoured on you, and talks
Most like a madman: you did never hear
A frantic, so in love with his own favour!
Now, you do know, 'tis of no validity
In your name, as you stand; therefore advise him
To put in me. (He's come here:) you shall share sir.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Vii.
div.stage: Wittipoll. Mistress fitz-dottrel. Manly. Meere-craft. Fitz-dottrell. Ever-ill. Plutarchus.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Madam, I have a suit to you; and a forehand,
I do bespeak you; you must not deny me,
I will be granted.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, I must know it, though.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No lady; you must not know it: yet, you must too.
For the trust of it, and the fame indeed,
Which else were lost me. I would use your name,
But in a feoffment: make my whole estate
Over unto you: a trifle a thing of nothing,
Some eighteen hundred.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Alas! I understand not
Those things sir. I am a woman, and most loath,
To embark myself —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: You will not slight me, madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nor you'll not quarrel me?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No, sweet madam, I have
Already a dependence; for which cause
I do this: let me put you in, dear madam,
I may be fairly killed. he hopes to be the man.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You have your friends, sir,
About you here, for choice.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: She tells you right, sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Death, if she do, what do I care for that?
Say, I would have her tell me wrong.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why, sir,
If for the trust, you'll let me have the honour
To name you one.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, you do me honour, madam:
Who is't?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, no, sweet madam,
He's friend to him, with whom I ha'the dependence. she design ▪ Manly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O, might he be?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: One Wittipol: do you know him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Alas sir, he, a toy: this gentleman
A friend to him, no more than I am sir!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But will your ladyship undertake that, madam?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, and what else, for him, you will engage me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: His name is Eustace manly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Whence does he write himself?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Of Middlesex,
Esquire.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Say nothing, madam. Clerke, come hither,
Write Eustace manly, squire of Middlesex.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What ha'you done, sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Named a gentleman,
That I'll be answerable for, to you, sir.
Had I named you, it might ha' been suspected:
this way, 'tis safe.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, your hands,
Everil applauds it. for witness.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: You ha' made election
Of a most worthy gentleman!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Would one of worth
Had spoke it: whence it comes, it is
Rather a shame to me, than a praise.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir, I will give you any satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Be silent then: "Falsehood commends not truth.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: You do deliver this, sir, as your deed,
To th'use of Mr. manly?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes: and sir —
When did you see young Wittipol? I am ready,
For process now; sir, this is publication.
He shall hear from me, he would needs be courting
My wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes: so witnesseth his cloak there.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fitz-dottrel is suspicious of Manly still. nay good sir, — madam, you did undertake —

sp.speaker: What.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: That he was not Wittipol's friend.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I hear
Sir, no confession of it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O she knows not;
Now I remember, madam! This young Wittipol,
Would ha' debauched my wife, and made me cuckold,
Through a casement; he did fly her home
To mine own window: but I think I sou't him,
And ravished her away, out of his pounces.
I ha' sworn to ha' him by the ears: I fear
The toy, with not do me right.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No? that were pity!
What right do you ask, sir? Here he is will do't you?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wittipol discovers himself. ha? Wittipol?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I sir, no more lady now,
Nor Spaniard!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No indeed, 'tis Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Am I the thing I feared?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A cuckold? No sir,
But you were late in possibility,
I'll tell you so much.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But your wife's too virtuous!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: We'll see her sir, at home, and leave you here,
To be made Duke o'shore-ditch with a project.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Thieves, ravishers.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Cry but another note, sir,
he would have his deed again. I'll mar the tune, o'your pipe!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Gi'me my deed, then.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Neither: that shall be kept for your wives good,
Who will know, better how to use it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Have
To feast with my land?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, be you quiet,
Or I shall gag you, ere I go, consult
You master of dependences; how to make this
A second business, you have time sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Oh!
What will the ghost of my wise grandfather,
Wittipol baffles him, and goes out. my learned father, with my worshipful mother
Think of me now, that left me in this world
In state to be their heir? that am become
A cuckold, and an ass, and my wife's ward;
Likely to lose my land; ha' my throat cut:
All, by her practice!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, we are all abused!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And be so still! Who hinders you, I pray you,
Let me alone, I would enjoy myself,
And be the Duke o' Drowned-ladn, you ha' made me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, we must play an aftergame of this

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But I am not in case to be a gamester:
I tell you once again —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You must be ruled
And take some counsel.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Sir, I do hate counsel,
As I do hate my wife, my wicked wife!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But we may think how to recover all:
If you will act.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I will not think; nor act;
Nor yet recover; do not talk to me?
I'll run out o'my wits, rather than hear;
I will be what I am, Fabian Fitz dotterel,
Though all the world say nay to't.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let's follow him.

div.head: Act. v. scene. i.
div.l: But has my lady missed me?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Beyond telling!
Here has been that infinity of strangers!
And then she would ha' had you, to ha' sampled you
With, one within, that they are now a teaching;
And does pretend to your rank.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Good fellow Pitfall
Tell Mr. Mere-craft, I entreat a word with him.
This most unlucky accident will go nearpitfall goes out.
To be the loss o'my place; I am in doubt!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With me? what say you Mr. Ambler?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir,
I would beseech your worship stand between
Me, and my lady's displeasure, for my absence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, is this all? I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I would tell you sir
But how it happened.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Brief, good Mr. Ambler,
Put yourself to your rack:Meere-craft seems full of business for I have a task
Of more importance.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir you'll laugh at me!
But (So is truth) a very friend of mine,
Finding by conference with me, that I lived
Too chaste for my complexion (And indeed
Too honest for my place, sir) did advise me
If I did love myself (As that I do,
I must confess)

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Spare your parenthesis,

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: To give my body a little evacuation —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well, and you went to a whore?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No, sir. I durst not
(For fear it might arrive at somebody's ear,
It should not) trust myself to a common house;Ambler this too with extraordinary speed
But got the gentlewoman to go with me,
And carry her bedding to a conduit-head,
Hard by the place towards Tyburn, which they call
My l. major's banqueting-house. Now, sir, this morning
Was execution; and I ne'er dreamt on't,
Till I heard the noise o'the people, and the horses;
and neither I, nor the poor gentlewoman
Durst stir, till all was done and passed: so that
he stags i'the interim, we fell asleep again.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, if you fall, from your gallop, I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: But when I waked, to put on my clothes, a suit,
I made new for the action, it was gone,
And all my money, with my purse, and seals,
My hard-wax, and my table-books, my studies,
And a fine new device, I had to carry
My pen, and ink, my civet, and my toothpicks,
All under one. But, that which grieved me, was
The gentlewoman's shoes (With a pair of roses,
And garters, I had given her for the business)
So as that made us stay, till it was dark.
For I was fain to lend her mine, and walk
In a rug, by her, bare foot, to saint Giles's.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A kind of Irish penance! Is this all, sir?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: To satisfy my lady.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will promise you, sir.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I ha' told the true disaster.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I cannot stay wi'you
Sir, to condole; but gratulate your return.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: An honest gentleman, but he's never at leisure
To be himself: he has such tides of business.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Ii.
div.l: O, call me home again, dear chief, and put me
To yoking foxes, milking of he-goats,
Pounding of water in a mortar, laving
The sea dry with a nutshell, gathering all
The leaves are fallen this autumn, drawing farts
Out of dead bodies, making ropes of sand,
Catching the winds together in a net,
Mustering of ants, and numbering atoms; all
That hell, and you thought exquisite torments, rather
Than stay me here, a thought more: I would sooner
Keep fleas within a circle, and be accountant
A thousand year, which of'hem and how far
Out leaped the other, then endure a minute
Such as I have within. There is no hell
To a lady of fashion. All your tortures there
Are pastimes to it. 'twould be a refreshing
ambler comes in, and surveys 〈◊〉. for me, to be i'the fire again, from hence.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: This is my suit, and those the shoes and roses!

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: They've such impertinent vexations,
A general council of devils could not hit —
Ha! this is he I took asleep with his wench,
And borrowed his clothes. What might I do to balk him?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Answer but not to th'purpose.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What is your name,he answers quite from the purpose. I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Is't so late sir?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I ask not o'the time, but of your name, sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I thank you, sir. Yes it dos hold sir, certain.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Hold, sir? What holds? I must both hold, and talk to you
About these clothes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A very pretty lace!
But the tailor cozened me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No, I am cozened
By you! robbed.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Why, when you please sir, I am
For three penny gleek, your man.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Pox of your gleek,
And three pence. Give me an answer.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir,
My master is the best at it.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your master!
Who is your master.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Let it be Friday night.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What should be then?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Your best songs Tom of bedlam

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I think, you are he. Does he mock me trow, from purpose?
Or do not I speak to him, what I mean?
Good sir your name.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Only a couple a'cocks sir,
If we can get a widgeon, 'tis in season.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: He hopes to make one o'these sceptics o'mefor sceptics.
(I think I name him right) and does not fly me.
I wonder at that! 'tis a strange confidence!
I'll prove another way, to draw his answer.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Iii.
div.l: It is the easiest thing sir, to be done.
As plain, as fizzling: roll but wi' your eyes,
And foam at th'mouth. A little castle-soap
Will do't, to rub your lips: and then a nutshell,
With toe, and touchwood in it to spit fire,
Did you ne'er read, sir, little Darrel's tricks,
With the boy of Burton, and the 7 in Lancashire,
Summers at Nottingham? All these do teach it.
And we'll give out,they repair their old plot. sir, that your wife has bewitched you:

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And practised with those two, as sorcerers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And ga' you potions, by which means you were
Not compos mentis, when you made your feoffment.
There's no recovery o'your estate, but this:
This, sir, will sting.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And move in a court of equity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For it is more than manifest, that this was
A plot o'your wives, to get your land.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I think it.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir it appears.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay and my cousin has known
These gallants in these shapes.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: T'have done strange things, sir.
One as the lady, the other as the squire.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How, a man's honesty may be fooled! I thought him
A very lady.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: So do I: renounce me else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But this way, sir you'll be revenged at height.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Upon 'em all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes faith, and since your wife
has run the way of woman thus, e'en give her —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Lost by this hand, to me; dead to all joys
Of her dear dotterel, I shall never pity her:
That could, pity herself.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Princely resolved sir,
And like yourself still, in potentiâ.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Mere-craft, etc. to them. Gvilt-head. Sledge. Plutarchus. Serjants.
div.l: Fitz dotterel asks for his money. Guilt-head what news?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O sir, my hundred pieces:
Let me ha'them yet.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Yes sir, officers
Arrest him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I arrest you.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Keep the peace,
I charge you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Arrest me? Why?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: For better security, sir. My son Plutarchus
Assures me, you're not worth a groat.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Pardon me, father,
I said his worship had no foot of land left:
And that I'll justify, for I writ the deed.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ha'you these tricks i'the city?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Yes, and more.
meaning mere-craft.arrest this gallant too, here, at my suit.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Ay, and at mine. He owes me for his lodging
Two year and a quarter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why m. Guilt-head, landlord,
Thou art not mad, though thou'rt constable
Puffed up with the pride of the place? Do you hear, sirs.
Have I deserved this from you two? for all
My pains at court, to get you each a patent.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: the project of forks. for what?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Uponmy project of the forks.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Forks? what be they?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The laudable use of forks,
Brought into custom here, as they are in Italy,
To th'sparing o'napkins. That, that should have made
Your bellows go at the forge, as his at the furnace.
I ha' procured it, ha'the signet for it,
Dealt with the linendrapers, on my private,
By cause, I feared, they were the likeliest ever
To stir against, to cross it: for 'twill be
A mighty saver of linen through the kingdom
(As that is one o'my grounds, and so spare washing)
Now, on you two, had I laid all the profits.
Guilt-head to have the making of all those
Of gold and silver, for the better personages;
And you of those of steel for the common sort.
And both by patent, I had brought you your seals in.
Sledge is brought about. but now you have prevented me, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Sir, I will bail you, at my own apperill.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: and Guilt-head comes. nay choose.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Do you so too, good father.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I like the fashion o'the project, well,
The forks! It may be a lucky one! and is not
Intricate, as one would say, but fit for
Plain heads, as ours, to deal in. Do you hear.
Officers, we discharge you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why this shows
A little good nature in you, I confess,
But do not tempt your friends thus. Little Guilt-head,
Advise your fire, great Guilt-head from these courses:
And, here, to trouble a great man in reversion,
For a matter o'fifty on a false alarm,
Away, it shows not well. Let him get the pieces
And bring 'em. You'll hear more else.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Ambler.
sp.l: O master Sledge, are you here? I ha' been to seek you.
You are the constable, they say. Here's one
That I do charge with felony, for the suit
He wears, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Who? M. Fitz-dottrel's man?
Ware what you do, m. Ambler.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir, these clothes
I'll swear, are mine: and the shoes the gentlewoman's
I told you of: and ha'him afore a justice,
I will.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: My master, sir, will pass his word for me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: O,Fitz-dottrel disclaims him. can you speak to purpose now?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Not I,
If you be such a one sir, I will leave you
To your godfathers in law. Let twelve men work.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Do you hear sir, pray, in private.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, what say you?
Brief, for I have no time to lose.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Truth is, sir,
I am the very devil, and had leave
To take this body, I am in, to serve you:
Which was a cutpurse's, and hanged this morning.
And it is likewise true, I stole this suit
To clothe me with. But sir let me not go
To prison for it. I have hitherto
Lost time, done nothing; shown, indeed, no part.
O'my devil's nature. Now, I will so help
Your malice, 'gainst these parties: so advance
The business, that you have in hand of witchcraft,
And your possession, as myself were in you.
Teach you such tricks, to make your belly swell,
And your eyes turn, to foam, to stare, to gnash
Your teeth together, and to beat yourself,
Laugh loud, and feign six voices —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Out you rogue!
You most infernal counterfeit wretch! Avaunt!
Do you think to gull me with your Aesop's fables?
Here take him to you, I ha' no part in him.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Away,and sends him away. I do disclaim, I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What said he to you, sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Like a lying rascal
Told me he was the devil.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How! A good jest!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And that he would teach me, such fine devil's tricks
For our new resolution.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: O'pox on him,
'twas excellent wisely done, sir, not to trust him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Merecraft gives the instructions to him and the rest. why, if he were the devil, we sha'not need him,
If you'll be ruled. Go throw yourself on a bed, sir,
And feign you ill. We'll not be seen wi'you,
Till after, that you have a fit: and all
Confirmed within. Keep you with the two ladies
And persuade them. I'll to justice Either-side,
And possess him with all. Trains shall seek out engine,
And they to fill the town with't, every cable
It is to be veered. We must employ out all
Our emissaries now; sir, I will send you
Bladders and bellows. Sir, be confident,
'Tis no hard thing t'outdo the devil in:
A boy o'thirteen year old made him an ass
But tother day.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, I'll begin to practice,
And scape the imputation of being cuckold,
By mine own act.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You're right.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, you ha'put
Yourself to a simple coil here, and your friends,
By dealing with new agents, in new plots.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No more o'that, sweet cousin.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: What had you
To do with this same Wittipol, for a lady?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Question not that: 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: You had some strain
Above e-la?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I had indeed.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And, now, you crack fort.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do not upbraid me.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, you must be told on't;
You are so covetous, still, to embrace
More than you can, that you lose all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis right.
What would you more, then guilty? Now, your succours.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Vi.
div.l: Here you are lodged, sir, you must send your garnish,
If you'll be private.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: There it is, sir, leave me.
Pug is brought to Newgate.to Newgate, brought? How is the name of devil
Discredited in me! What a lost fiend
Shall I be, on return? My chief will roar
In triumph, now, that I have been on earth,
A day, and done no noted thing, but brought
That body back here, was hanged out this morning.
enter iniquity the vice.well! would it once were midnight, that I knew
My utmost. I think time be drunk, and sleeps:
He is so still, and moves not! I do glory
Now i'my torment. Neither can I expect it,
I have it with my fact.

sp.speaker: Iniquity
sp.l: Child of hell, be thou merry ▪
Put a look on, as round, boy, and red as a cherry.
Cast care at thy posterns; and firk in thy fetters,
They are ornaments, baby, have graced thy betters ▪
Look upon me, and hearken. Our chief doth salute thee,
and lest the could iron should chance to confuse thee,
H'hath sent thee, grant-parole by me to stay longer
A month here on earth, against cold child, or hunger

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: How? longer here a month?

sp.speaker: Iniquity
sp.l: Yes, boy, till the session,
That so thou mayest have a triumphal egression.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: In a cart, to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Iniquity
sp.l: No, child, in a cart,
The chariot of triumph, which most of them are.
And in the mean time, to be greasy, and bouzy,
And nasty, and filthy, and ragged and lousy,
With damn me, renounce me, and all the fine phrases;
That bring, unto Tyburn, the plentiful gazes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: He is a devil! and may be our chief!
The great superior devil! for his malice:
Archdevil! I acknowledge him. He knew
What I would suffer, when he tied me up thus
In a rogue's body: and he has (I thank him)
His tyrannous pleasure on me, to confine me
To the unlucky carcase of a cutpurse
Wherein I could do nothing.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Impudent fiend,
