Stop thy lewd mouth. the great devil enters, and upbraids him with all his days work. dost thou not shame and tremble
To lay thine own dull damned defects upon
An innocent case, there? Why thou heavy slave!
The spirit, that did possess that flesh before
Put more true life, in a finger, and a thumb.
Then thou in the whole mass. Yet thou rebell'st
And murmur'st? What one proffer hast thou made,
Wicked enough, this day, that might be called
Worthy thine own, much less the name that sent thee?
First, thou didst help thyself into a beating
Promptly, and with't endangerd'st too thy tongue:
A devil, and could not keep a body entire
One day! That, for our credit. And to vindicate it,
Hinderdest (For ought thou knowest) a deed of darkness:
Which was an act of that egregious folly,
As no one, toward the devil, could ha'thought on.
This for your acting! but for suffering! why
Thou hast been cheated on, with a false beard,
And a turned cloak. Faith would your predecessor
The cutpurse, think you, ha' been so? Out upon thee,
The hurt thou'st done, to let men know their strength,
And that they are able to outdo a devil
Put in a body, will for ever be
A scar upon our name! whom hast thou dealt with,
Woman or man, this day, but have outgone thee
Some way, and most have proved the better fiends?
Yet, you would be employed ▪ yes, hell shall make you
Provincial o'the heaters! or bawd-ledger,
For this side o'the town! No doubt you'll render
A rare account of things. Bane o'your itch,
And scratching for employment. I'll ha' brimstone
to allay it sure, and fire to singe your nails off,
But, that I would not such a damned dishonour
Stick on our state, as that the devil were hanged;
And could not save a body, that he took
iniquity takes him on his back. from Tyburn, but it must come thither again:
You should e'en ride. But up away with him —

sp.speaker: Iniquity
sp.l: Mount, darling of darkness, my shoulders are broad:
He that caries the fiend, is sure of his load.
The devil was wont to carry away the evil;
But, now, the evil out-carries the devil.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Vii.
div.l: a great noise is heard in Newgate, and the keepers come out affrighted. o me!

sp.speaker: Keeper 1.
sp.l: What's this?
A piece of justice' hall
Is broken down.
Fough! what a steam of brimstone
Is here?
The prisoner's dead, came in but now!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ha? where?
Look here.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: 'Slid I should know his countenance!
It is Gil-cut-purse, was hanged out, this morning!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis he!
The devil, sure, has a hand in this!
What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Carry the news of it
Unto the sheriffs.
And to the justices.
This strange!
And savours of the devil, strongly!
I' ha' the sulphur of hell-coal i'my nose.
Fough.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Carry him in.
Away.
How rank it is!

div.head: Act. v. scene. Viii.
div.stage: Sir Poule. Meere-craft. Ever-ill. Trains. Pitfall. Fitz-dottrell. to them. Wittipoll. Manly. Mistress Fitz-dottrell. Ingine. to them Guilt-head. Sledge. to them. Shackles.
div.l: the justice comes out wondering and the rest informing him. this was the notablest conspiracy,
That ere I heard of.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, they had given him potions,
That did enamour him on the counterfeit lady —

sp.speaker: Eve ..
sp.l: Just to the time o'delivery o'the deed —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And then the witchcraft ''gan t'act, for straight
He fell into his fit.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Of rage at first, sir,
Which since has so increased.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good sir Poule, see him,
And punish the impostors.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Therefore I come, madam.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Let m. Either-side alone, madam.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Do you hear?
Call in the constable, I will have him by:
He's the King's officer! and some citizens,
Of credit! I'll discharge my conscience clearly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, sir, and send for his wife.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And the two sorcerers,
By any means!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I thought one a true lady,
I should be sworn. So did you, Either-side?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Yes, by that light, would I might ne'er stir else, Tailbush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And the other a civil gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: But, madam,
You know what I told your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I now see it:
I was providing of a banquet for 'em
After I had done instructing of the fellow
Devil, the gentleman's man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Who's found a thief, madam.
And to have robbed your usher, master Ambler
This morning.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I'll tell you more, anon.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Gi'me some garlic, garlic, garlic, garlic.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hark the poor gentleman,he begins his fit. how he is tormented!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: My wife is a whore, I'll kiss her no more: and why?
Mayest not thou be a cuckold as well as I?
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, etc.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: That is the devil speaks, and laughs in him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you think so sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I discharge my conscience. the justice interpret all

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And is not the devil good company? Yes, wis.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: How he changes, sir, his voice!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And a cuckold is
Where ere he put his head, with a wanion,
If his horns be forth, the devil's companion!
Look, look, look, else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How he foams!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And swells!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, me! what's that there, rises in his belly!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: A strange thing! hold it down:

sp.speaker: Tra. Pit.
sp.l: We cannot, madam.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: 'Tis too apparent this!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wittipol,Wittipol, and Manly and mist. Fitz-dottrel enter. Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How now, what play ha' we here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What fine new, matters?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: The coxcomb, and the coverlet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O strange impudence!
That these should come to face their sin!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And out-face
Justice, they are the parties, sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Say nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Did you mark, sir, upon their coming in,
How he called Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And never saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I warrant you did I, let 'em play a while.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Buz, buz, buz, buz.

sp.speaker: Tay
sp.l: Lass poor gentleman!
How he is tortured! mist. Fit fie, master Fitz-dottrel!
What do you mean to counterfeit thus?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O,his wife goes to him o,
She comes with a needle, and thrusts it in,
She pulls out that, and she puts in a pin,
And now, and now, I do not know how, nor where,
But she pricks me here, and she pricks me there: ôh, ôh,

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Woman forbear.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What, sir?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: A practice foul
For one so fair:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hath this, then, credit with you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do you believe in't?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'll discharge
My conscience: 'tis a clear conspiracy ▪
A dark and devilish practice! I detest it!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: The justice sure will prove to be the merrier!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This is most strange, sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Come not to confront
Authority with insolence: I tell you,
I do detest it. Here comes the King's constable,
And with him a right worshipful commoner;
My good friend, master Guilt-head! I am glad
I can before such witnesses, profess
My conscience, and my detestation of it.
Horrible! most unnatural! Abominable!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: they whisper him. you do not rumble enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wallow, gnash:

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, how he is vexed!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: 'Tis too manifest.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: and give soap to act with. give him more soap to foam with, now lie still.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And act a little.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: What does he now, sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Show
The taking of tobacco, with which the devil
Is so delighted.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Hum!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: And calls for hum.
You takers of waters and tobacco,
Mark this.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yellow, yellow, yellow, yellow, etc.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: That's starch! the devil's idol of that colour.
He ratifies it, clapping of his hands.
The proofs are pregnant.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: How the devil can act!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: He is the master of players? Master Guilt-head,
And poets, too! you heard him talk in rhyme!
sir Poule interprets Figgum a jugglers's game. I had forgotten to observe it to you, ere while!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: See, he spits fire.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: O no, he plays at Figgum,
The devil is the author of wicked Figgum —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why speak you not unto him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If I had
All innocence of man to be endangered
And he could save, or ruin it: I'd not breathe
A syllable in request, to such a fellow,
I'd rather fall.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O they whisper, they whisper, whisper, etc.
We shall have more, of devils a score,
To come to dinner, in me the sinner.

sp.speaker: Eyt.
sp.l: Alas, poor gentleman!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Put 'em asunder.
Keep 'em one from the other.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Are you frantic, sir,
Or what grave dotage moves you, to take part
With so much villainy? we are not afraid
Either of law, or trial; let us be
Examined what our ends were, what the means,
To work by; and possibility of those means.
Do not conclude against us, ere you hear us.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will not hear you, yet I will conclude
Out of the circumstances.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Will you so, sir?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Yes they are palpable:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not as your folly:

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will discharge my conscience, and do all
To the meridian of justice.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: You do well, sir:

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Provide me to eat, three or four dishes o'good meat,
I'll feast them, and their trains, a justice' head and brains
Shall be the first.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: The devil loves not justice,
There you may see.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A spare-rib o'my wife,
And a whore's purtenance! A Guilt-head whole.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Be not you troubled, sir, the devil speaks it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, wis, knight, shite, Poule, jowl, owl, foul, troll, bowl.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Crambe, another of the devil's games!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Speak, sir, some Greek, if you can. Is not the justice
A solemn gamester?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: He curses
In Greek, I think.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Your Spanish, that I taught you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Queen brémosel ojo de burlas.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: How? your rest —
Let's break his neck in jest, the devil says,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Di gratia, signior mio se baúete denári fataméne part.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What, would the devil borrow money?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ouy,
Ouy, monsiur, ùn pàuure diable! Diablet in!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: It is the devil, by his several languages.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Where's sir Paul Either-side?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Here,enter the keeper of Newgate what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O! such an accident fallen out at Newgate, sir:
A great piece of the prison is rent down!
The devil has been there, sir, in the body —
Of the young cutpurse, was hanged out this morning,
But in new clothes, sir, every one of us know him.
These things were found in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Those are mine, sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I think he was committed on your charge, sir.
For a new felony

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He's gone, sir, now,
And left us the dead body. But with all, sir,
Such an infernal stink, and steam behind,
You cannot see st. Pulchar's steeple, yet.
They smell't as far as ware, as the wind lies,
By this time, sure.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Is this upon your credit, friend?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Sir,Fitx. dotterel leaves counterfeiting. you may see, and satisfy yourself.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, then, 'tis time to leave off counterfeiting.
Sir I am not bewitched, nor have a devil ▪
No more than you. I do defy him, ay,
And did abuse you. These two gentlemen
Put me upon it. (I have faith against him)
They taught me all my tricks. I will tell truth,
And shame the fiend. See, here, sir are my bellows,
And my fall belly, and my mouse, and all
That should ha'come forth?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, are not you ashamed
Now of your solemn, serious vanity?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will make honourable amends to truth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And so will I. But these are cozeners, still;
And ha' my land, as plotters, with my wife:
Who, though she be not a witch, is worse, a whore.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, you belie her. She is chaste, and virtuous,
And we are honest. I do know no glory
A man should hope, by venting his own follies,
But you'll still be an ass, in spite of providence.
Please you go in, sir, and here truths, then judge 'em:
And make amends for your late rashness; when,
●o● shall but here the pains and care was taken,
To save this fool from ruin (His grace of drowned land)

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: My land is drowned indeed —

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And how much
Is modest and too worthy wife hath suffered
● misconstruction, from him, you will blush,
First for your own belief, more for his actions!
〈◊〉 land is his: and never, by my friend,
〈◊〉 by myself, meant to another use,
〈◊〉 for her succours, who hath equal right.
If any other had worse counsels in't,
(I know I speak to those can apprehend me)
Let 'em repent 'em, and be not detected.
It is not manly to take joy, or pride
In humane errors (We do all ill things,
They do 'em worst that love 'em, and dwell there,
Till the plague comes) the few that have the seeds
Of goodness left, will sooner make their way
To a true life, by shame, than punishment.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: Thus, the projector, here, is overthrown.
But I have now a project of mine own,
If it may pass: that no man would invite
The poet from us, to sup forth tonight ,
If the play please. If it displeasant be,
We do presume, that no man will: nor we:

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
